title: Definition of a Bar Graph
text: Bar graphs show different bars that are separated from one another, separating categorical data into their categories. The bars are rectangles that can be horizontal or vertical.
speech: Bar graphs show different bars that are separated from one another, separating categorical data into their categories. The bars are rectangles that can be horizontal or vertical.
pacedSpeech: Bar graphs show different bars that are separated from one another, separating categorical data into their categories. The bars are rectangles that can be horizontal or vertical.

title: Determining the Categories for the Bars
text: Since we're using vertical bars, our horizontal axis will list out the categories. Are the categories the ages or the proportions? Think about how we're separating the data into different groups. What are those groups?
speech: Since we're using vertical bars, our horizontal axis will list out the categories. Are the categories the ages or the proportions? Think about how we're separating the data into different groups. What are those groups?
pacedSpeech: Since we're using vertical bars, our horizontal axis will list out the categories. Are the categories the ages or the proportions? Think about how we're separating the data into different groups. What are those groups?

title: Determining the Horizontal Axis
text: Knowing that the categories are ages, which graph can we EXCLUDE?

subHints.title: Determining the Horizontal Axis
subHints.text: Which graph does not have ages on the horizontal axis?

speech: Knowing that the categories are ages, which graph can we EXCLUDE?
pacedSpeech: Knowing that the categories are ages, which graph can we EXCLUDE?

title: Determining Correctness of Bins
text: From the three remaining graphs, Graph A, B, and D, we can determine next which ones use the accurate "bins" for the ages.
speech: From the three remaining graphs, Graph A, B, and D, we can determine next which ones use the accurate "bins" for the ages.
pacedSpeech: From the three remaining graphs, Graph A, B, and D, we can determine next which ones use the accurate "bins" for the ages.

title: Determining Correctness of Bins
text: Which graph does not use the correct bins? In effect, which graph's age groups is incorrect?
speech: Which graph does not use the correct bins? In effect, which graph's age groups is incorrect?
pacedSpeech: Which graph does not use the correct bins? In effect, which graph's age groups is incorrect?

title: Correctness of Data Values for Each Bin
text: Now we're down to the final two: Graph A and Graph B. To determine which bar graph is correct, we must determine which one uses the correct data points. For instance, the proportion for the $$13-25$$ age group should be 45%, for the $$26-44$$ age group should be 36%, and the proportion for the $$45-64$$ age group should be 19%.
speech: Now we're down to the final two: Graph A and Graph B. To determine which bar graph is correct, we must determine which one uses the correct data points. For instance, the proportion for the  13 minus 25  age group should be 45%, for the  26, minus 44  age group should be 36%, and the proportion for the  45, minus 64  age group should be 19%.

title: Correctness of Data Values for Each Bin
